senses.sense_definition: A curt or uninterested dismissal; a failure to respond adequately to someone.

examples.text: He tried to schedule a meeting with the director, but he was given the <w>blowoff</w>.
Her vague response to my invitation felt like a polite <w>blowoff</w>.

senses.sense_definition: A class or task that requires very little effort to pass or complete.

examples.text: Most seniors try to find a <w>blowoff</w> class to take during their final semester.
The professor warned the students that his physics course was definitely not a <w>blowoff</w>.

senses.sense_definition: The act of releasing pressure, steam, or liquid from a machine or container.

examples.text: The mechanic monitored the <w>blowoff</w> from the boiler to ensure the pressure remained safe.
Regular <w>blowoff</w> of the accumulated sediment is necessary for the maintenance of the pipes.

senses.sense_definition: A period of rapid and usually unsustainable increase in market prices.

examples.text: Investors worried that the sudden rally was just a <w>blowoff</w> before a major crash.
The stock chart showed a classic <w>blowoff</w> pattern with extremely high trading volume.
